Judul: DESIGNING OF SOCIAL FORESTRY PROGRAM IN THE MOUNT CIREMAI NATIONAL PARK BASED ON VALUATION OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICES
Abstrak:
A conservation area is a designated area that serves the purpose of preserving flora,
fauna, and wildlife, as well as stabilizing the hydrological cycle, protecting the soil
and water reservoir, and maintaining the natural environmental balance. However,
environmental constraints, including depletion of natural resources, income
limitation of surrounding communities, increasing human population, and
budgetary constraints for conservation programs challenge the conservation area
management. To tackle these issues, collaborative management is needed to ensure
resource sustainability, the economic prosperity of community, and reduction of the
budget to manage the forest area. The first step to achieve this goal is to increase
community awareness, especially through information and knowledge provision
about the value of ecosystem services produced from a forest area. By using a
quantitative approach of valuation-spatial analysis and cost-benefit analysis, this
research aims to analyze the valuation of ecosystem services based on water
production, erosion protection, and pollination trees. This research finally proposes
a feasible and useful social forestry program that can improve the welfare of the
community and increase awareness among them about the conservation area.
We obtained the basic information from the InVEST model that the MCNP area of
15,500 ha can produce water up to 1.5 million m3/year or equivalent to IDR 5.22
billion/year. The Universal Soil Loss Equation (USLE) method showed 3,125 ha
with potential for landslides in several MCNP locations. Furthermore, intensive
forest management interventions at bare forest locations can increase water volume
up to 72,568 m3/year and reduce the risk of landslides. Based on information on
ecosystem services, most respondents are willing to pay for those with an average
WTP of IDR 79,860/month, while those who cannot afford to pay are willing to do
voluntary work for 3.49 days/month or equal to IDR 279,040/month. In pollination
trees, the development of honeybee culture, with an assumption that the cultivation
can develop in 36 villages, can produce a profit of 144 million/year. The result of
the cost-benefit analysis shows positive net present value at 3%, 6%, and 9%
discount rates, indicating that the social forestry program is acceptable and feasibleii
to run. Based on research and literature studies, the program that can be developed
in the MCNP is the apiculture social forestry program. The stages of the program
are communicative action, strategic action, and instrumental action. The design of
a social forestry program will provide socioeconomic benefits to the community
around the MCNP area and boost the effectiveness of management of the MCNP
area.
